text:
Vanuatu's economy is primarily agricultural; 80% of the population is engaged
in agricultural activities that range from subsistence farming to smallholder
farming of coconuts and other cash crops.

Copra is by far the most important cash crop (making up more than 35% of
Vanuatu's exports), followed by timber, beef, and cocoa. Kava root extract
exports also have become important.
openai_summarised_points: • Vanuatu's economy is predominantly agricultural, with approximately 80% of the population involved in agricultural activities.
• Agricultural activities in Vanuatu encompass a spectrum from subsistence farming to smallholder farming focused on coconuts and other cash crops.
• Copra is the most significant cash crop in Vanuatu, accounting for more than 35% of the country's exports.
• Other notable export commodities include timber, beef, and cocoa.
• Exports of kava root extract have recently gained importance in Vanuatu's economy.

text:
In addition, the Vanuatu government has maintained the country's pre-
independence status as a tax haven and international financial center. About
2,000 registered institutions offer a wide range of offshore banking,
investment, legal, accounting, and insurance and trust company services. On
the Tax Justice Network's 2011 Financial Secrecy Index, Vanuatu received a
"secrecy score" of 88/100, though its marginal market share placed it near the
bottom of the weighted list. Vanuatu was one of three Pacific island nations
(along with Nauru and Palau) which four major international banks placed a
U.S. dollar transaction ban on in December 1999. Vanuatu sells citizenship for
about $150,000, and its passports allow visa-free travel throughout Europe.
With demand from the Chinese market booming, passport sales may now account
for more than 30% of the country's revenue. Vanuatu maintains an international
shipping register in New York City.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • The Vanuatu government has preserved the country's pre-independence status as a tax haven and international financial center, supporting a significant offshore financial services sector.
• Approximately 2,000 registered institutions operate in Vanuatu, providing a diverse array of offshore banking, investment, legal, accounting, insurance, and trust company services.
• In the Tax Justice Network's 2011 Financial Secrecy Index, Vanuatu received a high "secrecy score" of 88 out of 100, indicating a strong level of financial secrecy.
• Despite the high secrecy score, Vanuatu's relatively small market share placed it near the bottom of the weighted list in the 2011 Financial Secrecy Index.
• In December 1999, Vanuatu was one of three Pacific island nations—along with Nauru and Palau—subjected to a U.S. dollar transaction ban imposed by four major international banks.
• Vanuatu offers citizenship for approximately $150,000, with its passports granting visa-free travel throughout Europe, enhancing the appeal of its citizenship program.
• The demand for Vanuatu passports, particularly from the Chinese market, has surged, with passport sales potentially accounting for more than 30% of the country's national revenue.
• Vanuatu maintains an international shipping register based in New York City, facilitating its maritime and shipping industry operations.

text:
There is substantial fishing activity, although this industry does not bring
in much foreign exchange. Vanuatu claims an exclusive economic zone of 680,000
square kilometres (260,000 sq mi) and possesses marine resources.[_citation
needed_] Some ni-Vanuatu are involved in fishing, along with foreign fleets.
openai_summarised_points: • The fishing industry in Vanuatu involves substantial fishing activity, indicating a significant level of engagement in fishing practices within the country.
• Despite the considerable fishing activity, the industry does not generate a large amount of foreign exchange revenue for Vanuatu.
• Vanuatu asserts sovereignty over an exclusive economic zone (EEZ) encompassing 680,000 square kilometres (260,000 square miles), which provides access to extensive marine resources.
• Both indigenous ni-Vanuatu fishers and foreign fishing fleets participate in fishing operations within Vanuatu’s maritime zones.

text: In contrast, mining activity is unsubstantial.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • Mining activity in Vanuatu is described as unsubstantial, indicating that it plays a minimal role in the country's economy.
• Vanuatu's agricultural exports primarily include copra, kava, beef, cocoa, and timber, while its imports consist mainly of machinery and equipment, foodstuffs, and fuels.
• Copra, cocoa, kava, and beef collectively represent more than 60% of Vanuatu's total export value, highlighting their significance in the nation's trade portfolio.
• The agricultural sector contributes approximately 20% to Vanuatu's Gross Domestic Product (GDP), underscoring its importance to the overall economy.
• In 2018, Vanuatu produced 374 thousand tons of coconut, making it the largest agricultural product by volume for that year.
• The production of root and tubers in 2018 amounted to 53 thousand tons, indicating a substantial output of these staple crops.
• Banana production in Vanuatu reached 16 thousand tons in 2018, reflecting its role in the country's agricultural diversity.
• Vegetable production totaled 13 thousand tons in 2018, contributing to the domestic food supply and agricultural variety.

• Smaller-scale agricultural products in 2018 included peanut production at 2.6 thousand tons and cocoa at 1.8 thousand tons, demonstrating the presence of niche crops within Vanuatu's agricultural sector.

text:
Tourism is Vanuatu's fastest-growing sector, having comprised 40% of GDP in
2000. Industry's portion of GDP declined from 15% to 10% between 1990 and
2008. Government consumption accounted for about 27% of GDP.

Vanuatu has commodities, mostly agricultural, produced for export. In 2000,
imports exceeded exports by a ratio of nearly 4 to 1. This was offset by high
services income from tourism, which kept the current account balance fairly
even. After a downturn in 2001 and 2002 due to a decrease in tourism
funding,[_clarification needed_] the economy was expected to grow by 3.9%,
increasing to 4.3% in 2007.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • Tourism is identified as Vanuatu's fastest-growing economic sector, constituting 40% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in the year 2000.
• The industrial sector's share of Vanuatu's GDP declined from 15% in 1990 to 10% in 2008, indicating a relative decrease in industrial output or contribution over this period.
• Government consumption represented approximately 27% of Vanuatu's GDP, reflecting the significant role of public sector expenditure in the economy.
• Vanuatu's export commodities are primarily agricultural products, highlighting the country's reliance on agriculture for foreign exchange earnings.
• In the year 2000, Vanuatu's imports exceeded its exports by nearly a 4 to 1 ratio, demonstrating a substantial trade imbalance favoring imports.
• Despite the trade deficit, Vanuatu maintained a fairly balanced current account due to substantial income from tourism-related services, which offset the import-export disparity.
• The tourism sector experienced a downturn in 2001 and 2002, attributed to a decrease in tourism funding, which negatively impacted the overall economy during this period.

• Following the downturn, economic growth was projected to recover, with an expected growth rate of 3.9% initially, increasing to 4.3% by 2007, indicating optimism for the sector's and the economy's expansion.

text:
Luganville, the second largest city, is a hub for exports with 64.3% of
domestic exports leaving it compared to 35.7% for the capital of Port Vila,
whereas imports show the opposite trend with 86.9% entering through the
capital and 13.1% through Luganville.
openai_summarised_points: • Luganville, the second largest city in Vanuatu, serves as a primary hub for the country’s exports, handling 64.3% of domestic exports.
• In contrast, the capital city, Port Vila, accounts for 35.7% of Vanuatu’s domestic exports.
• The import distribution in Vanuatu exhibits an opposite pattern, with Port Vila receiving the majority of imports at 86.9%.
• Luganville handles a significantly smaller portion of imports, accounting for only 13.1% of the total imports entering Vanuatu.

text:
In 1997 the government, with the aid of the Asian Development Bank, committed
itself to a 3-year comprehensive reform program. During the first year of the
program the government has adopted a value-added tax, consolidated and
reformed government-owned banks, and started a 10% downsizing in the public
service.[_citation needed_] The program was derailed when Barak Sope became
prime minister. Under Prime Minister Edward Natapei, reform programs were
reintroduced.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • In 1997, the government of Vanuatu, with assistance from the Asian Development Bank, committed to implementing a comprehensive reform program spanning three years.
• During the first year of this reform program, the government introduced a value-added tax (VAT) as part of its fiscal policy adjustments.
• The reform efforts included the consolidation and restructuring of government-owned banks to improve financial sector efficiency.
• A 10% reduction in the public service workforce was initiated to downsize government operations and reduce expenditure.
• The reform program experienced a setback when Barak Sope assumed the office of Prime Minister, leading to a derailment of the ongoing reforms.
• Subsequently, under the leadership of Prime Minister Edward Natapei, the government reintroduced and renewed efforts to continue the reform programs.

text:
The government declared 2007 to be "the Year of the Traditional Economy"
(Bislama: _kastom ekonomi_), encouraging the trade of sea shells and pig tusks
and discouraging cash transfers. By the end of the year, they extended the
experiment in to 2008. The establishment of the Tangbunia Bank, to deal in
customary wealth, was linked to this initiative.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2007, the government of Vanuatu officially declared the year as "the Year of the Traditional Economy" (Bislama: _kastom ekonomi_), aiming to promote indigenous economic practices.
• This initiative encouraged the use and trade of traditional forms of wealth, specifically sea shells and pig tusks, as mediums of exchange within the community.
• Concurrently, the government discouraged the use of cash transfers during this period to reinforce the value of customary economic transactions.
• Due to the perceived success or ongoing interest in this initiative, the government extended the "Year of the Traditional Economy" experiment into 2008.
• The establishment of the Tangbunia Bank, an institution designed to handle and manage customary wealth, was directly associated with and supported by this government initiative.

text:
Vanuatu scored 32.06 (versus a worldwide score of 42.94, lower scores
translating to higher risk) on the June 2013 Euromoney Country Risk rankings.

All "$" units are US Dollar.

openai_summarised_points: • In the June 2013 Euromoney Country Risk rankings, Vanuatu scored 32.06, compared to a worldwide average score of 42.94, with lower scores indicating higher risk.
• All monetary values mentioned are expressed in US Dollars.
• Vanuatu's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) based on purchasing power parity was estimated at $1.237 billion in 2012.
• The real GDP growth rate for Vanuatu was estimated at 2.6% in 2012.
• GDP per capita, measured by purchasing power parity, was approximately $4,900 in 2012.
• The composition of Vanuatu's GDP by sector in 2012 was: agriculture 20.6%, industry 11.7%, and services 67.6%.
• Data on the percentage of the population below the poverty line is not available (NA%).
• Household income or consumption shares for the lowest 10% and highest 10% of the population are not available (NA%).
• The inflation rate, based on consumer prices, was estimated at 2.8% in 2012.
• The labor force numbered approximately 115,900 individuals as of 2007.
• Labor force distribution by occupation in 2010 was: agriculture 58%, industry 10%, and services 32%.
• The unemployment rate was estimated at 1.5% in 2010.
• Vanuatu's government budget in 2012 included revenues of $188.2 million and expenditures of $207.4 million, which incorporated capital expenditures of $700,000.
• Key industries in Vanuatu include food and fish freezing, wood processing, and meat canning.
• The industrial production growth rate was estimated at 12% in 2011.
• Electricity production in 2008 totaled 52 gigawatt-hours (GWh).
• In 2012, electricity production sources were composed of 90% fossil fuels, 0% hydroelectric, 0% nuclear, and 10% from other sources.
• Electricity consumption was recorded at 40.22 GWh in 2008.
• Electricity exports amounted to 220 kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 2008, while electricity imports were zero kWh in the same year.
• Major agricultural products include copra, coconuts, cocoa, coffee, kava, taro, yams, fruits, vegetables, fish, and beef.
• Total exports were valued at $280 million (free on board) in 2012.
• Principal export commodities included copra, beef, cocoa, timber, kava, and coffee.
• The main export partners in 2011 were Thailand (57.3%) and Japan (21.8%).
• Imports totaled $242 million (free on board) in 2012.
• Major import commodities consisted of machinery and equipment, foodstuffs, and fuels.
• Primary import partners in 2011 were China (26.7%), Singapore (21.2%), Australia (13.6%), New Zealand (7.2%), Fiji (6.7%), and Japan (5.4%).
• External debt stood at $307.7 million in 2011.
• Vanuatu received economic aid amounting to $27.5 million in 2002.
• The national currency is the vatu (VT), which has no subdivisions.
• The fiscal year in Vanuatu corresponds to the calendar year.
